The rigorous operating conditions required for propane dehydrogenation result in undesired side reactions on Pt catalysts. Herein, we present the successful suppression of structure-sensitive side reactions by modifying Pt/Al2O3 catalysts with P. The characterization of the P-modified Pt/Al2O3 catalysts revealed the coexistence of metallic Pt and Pt–P alloys on the surfaces of the Pt nanoparticles. At a reaction temperature of 600 °C, the Pt catalyst modified with an optimal amount of P exhibited a notably higher propylene selectivity (95%) than that of the unmodified Pt/Al2O3 catalyst (typically ∼83%), without any loss of activity. A detailed investigation revealed that the geometric effect resulting from the formation of the Pt–P alloy, which reduced the size of the Pt ensembles, was mainly responsible for the enhanced performance of P-modified Pt/Al2O3. This study offers vital insights into the formation of noble metal–P alloys on nanoparticle surfaces and their advantageous effects on heterogeneous catalysis. The growing demand for chemical products has led to an increased need for propylene. The low propylene selectivity obtained from naphtha via conventional steam cracking and fluid catalytic cracking has prompted the development of highly selective processes for propylene production. The abundant supply of propane from natural and shale gases has motivated the development of a direct dehydrogenation process for propane to produce propylene. Direct propane dehydrogenation (PDH; C3H8 → C3H6 + H2) requires high temperatures exceeding 550 °C to achieve a satisfactory propylene yield due to the endothermic nature of the reaction and its thermodynamic limitation [3–5]. As a catalytic material for PDH, Pt exhibits a superior selectivity toward propylene. However, unfavorable operating conditions such as high temperatures and hydrogen co-feeding lead to side reactions, including coke formation and hydrogenolysis, which reduce the propylene selectivity of monometallic Pt catalysts [3,6–8]. Previous studies on monometallic Pt catalysts have demonstrated that the size of Pt nanoparticles (NPs) plays a significant role in propylene selectivity, with atomically dispersed Pt exhibiting higher selectivity than that exhibited by sub-nanoclusters (2–5 nm) [7,9,10]. This is attributed to the fact that undesired reactions, such as hydrogenolysis, cracking, and coke formation, are structure-sensitive and are favored on large Pt ensembles [3,8]. Heteroatom doping of Pt ensembles results in the fragmentation of large Pt ensembles into smaller ones, thereby effectively inhibiting side reactions on the Pt surface under PDH conditions. Several studies have reported that this geometric effect in bimetallic Pt catalysts enhances both the turnover frequency of propane and selectivity toward propylene [11–14]. The modification of Pt catalysts with Sn induces both the geometric effect and other promoting effects, such as the modification of the electronic state and redispersion of Pt species [15–17]. The excellent catalytic performance demonstrated by PtSn catalysts in PDH serves as a strong motivation for the modification of supported Pt catalysts with various heteroatoms. Recently, attempts have been made to incorporate P into noble metals to modify the structure and electronic state of the metal surface. Compared with the monometallic Ru/SiO2 catalyst, which is highly active in hydrogenolysis, the Ru2P/SiO2 and RuP/SiO2 catalysts exhibited significantly higher propylene selectivity in PDH [18]. P acted as a structural promoter to reduce the size of Ru ensembles and effectively suppressed hydrogenolysis side reactions under PDH conditions. PtP2/SiO2 catalysts, which were pretreated in a reducing environment at 550 °C before the PDH reaction, also exhibited a higher propylene selectivity than did Pt/SiO2 [19]. However, the PtP2/SiO2 catalysts showed significantly lower activity for propane conversion because of the formation of non-metallic PtP2 surfaces containing Pt2+ ions. The fact that metallic Pt is the active species for dehydrogenation suggests that a moderate surface modification of Pt with P, rather than complete incorporation, is necessary to achieve synergistic effects between Pt and P in PDH. In supported Pt catalysts, the degree of alloying in heteroatom-doped Pt catalysts is influenced by not only the interaction between the heteroatom and Pt but also the interaction between the heteroatom and support material. A stronger interaction of the heteroatom with the support helps alleviate the complete alloying of the Pt catalyst [20,21]. Considering the stronger interaction between P and Al2O3 supports than between P and SiO2 supports, we prepared a series of P-modified Pt/Al2O3 catalysts with varying P loadings for PDH applications. The P-modified Pt/Al2O3 catalysts showed a moderate level of alloying between P and Pt, leading to the unique surface properties of Pt NPs. A synergistic effect between metallic Pt and the Pt–P alloy resulted in a significant improvement in propylene selectivity under various feed conditions. Detailed investigations provide insights into the underlying factors responsible for the enhanced performance of the P-modified Pt/Al2O3 catalysts. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation A series of P-modified Pt/Al2O3 catalysts, 1Pt–xP/Al2O3, with a target Pt loading of 1 wt% and P loading of x = 0–5 wt% were prepared via sequential wet impregnation using the following procedure. First, an unmodified Pt/Al2O3 catalyst, 1Pt–0P/Al2O3, was synthesized by dispersing 1 g of commercial γ-Al2O3 (SBET = 150 m2·g–1; SASOL) in 10 mL of deionized water and adding 22.6 mg of H2PtCl6·6 H2O (≥99.9 wt%; Sigma Aldrich;). The solution in the flask was stirred continuously at 55 °C until the solvent completely evaporated. The obtained powder was dried at 120 °C for 12 h and then calcined at 550 °C for 3 h. The synthesized 1Pt–0P/Al2O3 catalyst was used to prepare other P-modified Pt/Al2O3 catalysts, 1Pt–xP/Al2O3, such as 1Pt–1P/Al2O3, 1Pt–3P/Al2O3, and 1Pt–5P/Al2O3. For the sequential impregnation of P, an appropriate amount of H3PO4 (85.0%; Samchun) was introduced into a solution of 1Pt–0P/Al2O3 in deionized water. The solution was continuously stirred at 55 °C until the solvent completely evaporated. The obtained powder was dried at 120 °C for 12 h and then calcined at 550 °C for 3 h. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The Pt and P loadings of the 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 catalysts were determined via inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES). The specific surface areas and pore distributions of the catalysts were estimated using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) methods, respectively, from the data obtained using N2 physisorption at 77 K (Micromeritics ASAP 2010). The amount of CO adsorbed on the Pt NPs and the corresponding number of surface Pt atoms were estimated via CO chemisorption (MicrotracBEL BELCAT-Ⅱ). All of the samples were reduced by a gas mixture of 50 vol% H2/Ar at a total of 50 standard cubic centimeters per minute (sccm) at 600 °C for 1 h, and CO molecules were introduced at 50 °C using a pulse technique. The number of surface Pt atoms ( N Pt ), the surface area of the metal ( S A ), and the particle size ( d CO ) were calculated from the amount of chemisorbed CO on the catalysts [15,22]: N Pt [ mol · g cat – 1 ] = N CO × SF S A [ nm 2 · g – 1 ] = N Pt × N A × σ W Pt d CO [ nm ] = 6 S A × ρ where N CO is the amount of chemisorbed CO [mol·gcat –1], SF is the stoichiometry factor for CO chemisorption on Pt (SFCO/Pt = 1), N A is Avogadro’s constant [mol–1], σ is the cross-sectional area occupied by each Pt atom [nm2], W Pt is the weight of supported Pt per gram of sample [g·gcat –1], and ρ is the Pt metal density [g·nm–3]. High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) images were obtained using a JEOL JEM‐2100F FE-TEM instrument at 200 kV. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained using a Rigaku Ultima IV diffractometer with a Cu Kα radiation source (λ = 1.54 Å). The diffractometer was operated at 40 kV and 20 mA with a step size of 0.02 ° and a 2 °/min scan rate. X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) measurements were performed at the Pt L3-edge (11,564 eV), using the BL14B1 beamline at SPring-8 and the P65 beamline at DESY. The beam in both experiments was monochromated using a Si(111) crystal, and higher-order harmonics were eliminated by a Si mirror. The ionization chamber was filled with N2 to obtain an optimal transmission signal at the Pt L3-edge. The catalysts were placed in a reactor composed of a 1.5 mm diameter quartz capillary with a wall thickness of 0.01 mm. Subsequently, the capillary was supported on a stainless-steel holder with open ends to allow a gas flow. The samples were heated to 600 °C in pure He for 30 min and reduced under a flow of 3.5 vol% H2/He at 600 °C. XAS measurements were then performed, and the data were normalized using Athena software. The theoretical calculations for photoelectron backscattering amplitude and phase shift were performed using Feff9 software on the Pt foil, PtO2, and PtP2 compounds. The EXAFS fitting was performed to estimate the atomic pair distance (R), root-mean-square displacement (σ), and coordination number (CN). The passive electron reduction factor (S0 2) was estimated by fitting the EXAFS on Pt foil, which was found to be 0.9. Our samples are a mixture of metal and phosphides. For consistency, we kept the S0 2 the same for all the shells and were not varied during the fitting. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted using an Al Kα X-ray source (hν = 1486.6 eV) with a monochromator at the Korea Basic Science Institute, Busan. The Pt 4d binding energies were calibrated relative to the C 1s peak at 284.6 eV. Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) spectroscopy was performed using a Thermo Fisher Nicolet iS50 instrument. A 20 mg sample loaded into an adsorption cell (PIKE Technologies DiffusIR) was reduced by a gas mixture of 50 vol% H2/Ar (total 50 sccm) at 600 °C for 1 h and then cooled to 50 °C. For CO adsorption, the samples were exposed to 5 vol% CO/Ar gas (total 30 sccm) for 5 min, followed by purging with Ar gas (50 sccm) for 5 min to remove gaseous CO species in the cell. The DRIFT spectra after CO adsorption were recorded from 400 to 4000 cm–1 with a resolution of 4 cm–1. Temperature-programmed experiments were conducted using a MicrotracBEL BELCAT-II instrument. Before the measurements, a 100 mg sample was pre-reduced using a gas mixture of 50 vol% H2/He (total 50 sccm) at 600 °C for 1 h and then cooled to an appropriate temperature in a He flow for adsorption of a probe molecule. For propane temperature-programmed surface reaction (C3H8-TPSR) spectroscopy, the pre-reduced sample was exposed to a gas mixture of 3 sccm of C3H8, 3 sccm of H2, and 30 sccm of He at 50 °C and then heated to 600 °C at a rate of 5 °C·min–1. The desorbing products (C3H8, C3H6, C2H6, CH4, and H2) were monitored using mass spectrometer at m/z = 29, 41, 30, 16, and 2, respectively. For ammonia temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD), pretreated samples were exposed to a gas mixture containing 5 vol% NH3/He (total 50 sccm) for 30 min at 120 °C and then cooled to 80 °C in a He flow. While heating the sample to 800 °C at a rate of 5 °C·min–1 in a He flow (30 sccm), the amount of ammonia desorbed from the sample was monitored using a mass spectrometer (m/z = 15). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA; Hitachi STA 7300) was performed by loading 10 mg of spent catalyst into a sample pan and heating it to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C∙min–1 under an airflow (40 sccm). 2.3 Catalytic tests The performance of the catalysts for PDH was evaluated using a tubular fixed-bed quartz reactor at atmospheric pressure. The gas flow rates were regulated using calibrated mass-flow controllers. The reaction temperature was measured using a type-K thermocouple positioned at the top of the catalyst bed inside the reactor and was controlled using a proportional-integral-derivative controller. The powder catalyst was pelletized to obtain a uniform grain size of 150–425 μm, and 50 mg of the catalyst was used for performance measurements. First, the reactor was heated to the reaction temperature (600 °C) under an Ar flow for 1 h. Subsequently, the loaded catalyst was pretreated in a flow of 50 vol% H2/Ar gas (total 50 sccm) for 1 h. After purging the reactor with Ar for 15 min, a gas flow of 10 sccm C3H8, 10 sccm H2, and 80 sccm Ar (weight hourly space velocity, WHSVpropane = 23.6 h−1) was introduced into the reactor to evaluate the catalytic performance. For repeated measurements, the spent catalyst was regenerated by sequentially treating the sample in a flow of 21 vol% O2/N2 (total 25 sccm) for 10 min, Ar (100 sccm) for 15 min, and 50 vol% H2/Ar (total 50 sccm) for 1 h at the reaction temperature. To estimate the apparent activation energy (E a), 5 mg of the catalyst (WHSVpropane = 428 h–1) was used to maintain propane conversions below 10% at different reaction temperatures. The product gas was analyzed after 3 min of time on stream at 6 min intervals using an online gas chromatograph (YL6500, Younglin Instrument Co., Korea) equipped with a flame ionization detector. The propane conversion (X), product selectivity (S i ), turnover frequency of propane conversion ( TOF propane ), and space-time yield of propylene ( STY propylene ) were calculated using the following equations: X [ % ] = n propane in − n propane out n propane in × 100 S i [ % ] = a i 3 × n i n propane i n − n propane o ut × 100 TOF propane [ s – 1 ] = F propane in − F propane out N Pt × W cat S T Y p r o p y l e n e [ mmol · k g c a t – 1 · s – 1 ] = ( F propane i n − F propane out ) W cat × S propylene where n propane is the number of moles of propane, n i is the number of moles of the C1–C3 products (CH4, C2H4, C2H6, and C3H6), a i is the number of carbon atoms in the corresponding product, F propane is the molar flow rate of propane [mol·s–1], and W cat is the weight of catalyst [g]. In the calculations, coke deposition was not considered because the carbon balance was within ± 3% for all catalysts during the measurements (Fig. S1). To determine whether thermodynamic constraints affect propane conversion in our experimental conditions, the reaction quotient ( Q ) and equilibrium conversion ( X eq ) of propane were calculated based on the previous studies using the following modified equations [3,23,24]: Q = P C 3 H 6 × P H 2 P C 3 H 8 K eq = ( P C 3 H 8 X eq 2 + P H 2 X eq ) P 0 ( P 0 − P 0 X eq + P C 3 H 8 X eq − P C 3 H 8 X eq 2 ) where P i is the partial pressure of reactant and products [bar], K eq is the equilibrium constant when propane, H2, and inert gas are present, X eq is the equilibrium conversion of propane [%], and P 0 is the total pressure [bar]. The propane conversion measured over 1Pt–1P/Al2O3 catalyst was far from the corresponding equilibrium curve (Fig. S2). Moreover, the calculated approach-to-equilibrium ( Q / K eq ) values were significantly lower than 1, indicating that thermodynamic constraints were negligible under the experimental conditions (Table S1). The external and internal mass transfer limitations were assessed by applying the Mears (CM) and Weisz–Prater (CW–P) criteria, respectively, as follows [25,26]: C M = ( − r C 3 H 8 ) × ρ b × ( D cat ÷ 2 ) × n k c × C C 3 H 8 < 0.15 C W – P = ( − r C 3 H 8 ) × ρ cat × ( D cat ÷ 2 ) 2 D e × C C 3 H 8 < 0.6 where − r C 3 H 8 is the measured reaction rate per unit mass of catalyst [mol·gcat –1·s–1], ρ b is the bulk density of catalyst bed [gcat·m–3], ρ cat is the solid density of catalyst pellet [gcat·m–3], D cat is the diameter of catalyst particle [m], n is the reaction order, k c is the mass transfer coefficient [m·s–1], D e is the effective diffusivity [m2·s–1], and C C 3 H 8 is the bulk concentration of propane [mol·m–3]. The external and internal heat transfer limitations were evaluated by applying the criteria established by Mears and Anderson as follows [27,28]: ∣ − ∆ H ∣ × ( − r C 3 H 8 ) × ρ b × ( D cat ÷ 2 ) × E a h × T b 2 × R g < 0.15 ∣ − ∆ H ∣ × ( − r C 3 H 8 ) × ρ cat × ( D cat ÷ 2 ) × E a λ × T b 2 × R g < 0.75 where ∆ H is the heat of reaction [kJ·mol–1], − r C 3 H 8 is the measured reaction rate per unit mass of catalyst [mol·gcat –1·s–1], ρ b is the bulk density of catalyst bed [gcat·m–3], ρ cat is the solid density of catalyst pellet [gcat·m–3], D cat is the diameter of catalyst particle [m], E a is the apparent activation energy [kJ·mol–1], h is the heat transfer coefficient [W·m–2·K–1], λ is the thermal conductivity [W·m–1·K–1], T b is the reaction temperature [K], and R g is the gas constant [kJ·mol–1·K–1]. All estimated parameter values for the 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 catalysts were significantly lower than the criteria values, indicating that the mass and heat transfer limitations can be excluded in the experimental conditions (Table S2–S5). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Properties of P-modified Pt/Al2O3 catalysts A series of 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 catalysts with a target Pt loading of 1 wt% and P loading of x = 0–5 wt% were prepared via sequential wet impregnation of γ-Al2O3 with Pt and P precursors. Then, the 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 were reduced under the same pretreatment conditions as those for catalytic measurements, H2 atmosphere at 600 °C for 1 h, for characterizations. The actual Pt and P loadings in the 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 samples and their specific surface areas are listed in Table 1. All 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 samples exhibited Pt and P loadings close to the target values. The BET surface areas of 1Pt–0P/Al2O3 and 1Pt–1P/Al2O3 were nearly identical, but the surface areas of 1Pt–3P/Al2O3 and 1Pt–5P/Al2O3 were slightly lower. The slight decrease in surface area with increasing P loading suggests that the γ-Al2O3 support was impregnated with sufficient P. However, the modification of Pt/Al2O3 with P resulted in no significant change in the textural properties of the 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 catalysts, which all show similar N2 isotherms and pore-size distributions (Fig. S3). The HAADF-STEM images and size distributions of the Pt NPs in 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 are presented in Fig. 1 and Fig. S4, respectively. Pt NPs with sizes of 1–2 nm were well dispersed on the γ-Al2O3 support. With increasing P content, the average size of the Pt NPs slightly increased from 1.1 nm for 1Pt–0P/Al2O3 to 1.6 nm for 1Pt–5P/Al2O3 (Table 1). This can be attributed to the adsorption of P on the Pt NP surfaces or incorporation of P into the Pt NPs [12,19]. Because the characterization of 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 catalysts was hampered by the small size of the Pt NPs, the affinity of the P species for Pt NPs was further investigated via EDS imaging with the 3Pt–3P/Al2O3 sample, which has a higher Pt loading but the same Pt to P ratio as that of 1Pt–1P/Al2O3 (Fig. S5). The EDS images of 3Pt–3P/Al2O3 show the presence of the P species on the Pt NPs, suggesting the formation of P-modified Pt NPs in the 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 catalysts [29,30]. The crystal structures of 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 were investigated using XRD ( Fig. 2). Only the diffraction peaks corresponding to the γ-Al2O3 phase were observed for all catalysts. The absence of peaks corresponding to metallic Pt (2θ = 39.7° and 46.3°) and Pt–P crystallites (2θ = 26.8° and 52.8° for PtP2, JCPDS No. 03-065-9482) revealed that Pt NPs smaller than 3 nm were highly dispersed on the support [31,32]. These observations are consistent with the results obtained from the STEM images of 1Pt–xP/Al2O3. The change in the number of exposed Pt sites owing to P modification was estimated using CO chemisorption (Table 1). The probe molecule was selectively adsorbed on the metallic Pt sites and only a negligible amount of CO was adsorbed on the Al2O3 and P-modified Al2O3 supports. An increase in the P content of the 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 catalysts led to a significant decrease in the amount of CO chemisorbed onto the Pt NPs. Specifically, the number of moles of chemisorbed CO per mole of Pt decreased from 0.66 to 0.43, 0.16, and 0.14 when 1Pt–0P/Al2O3 was modified to 1Pt–1P/Al2O3, 1Pt–3P/Al2O3, and 1Pt–5P/Al2O3, respectively. All 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 catalysts show a similar level of average particle diameter between 1.1–1.6 nm in HAADF-STEM images. However, the average particle diameter estimated from the amount of CO on the Pt surface noticeably increases with increasing P content up to 7.6 nm for 1Pt–5P/Al2O3. The decrease in the amount of CO chemisorbed on Pt and the corresponding overestimation of the particle size indicate a loss of metallic Pt sites on the NP surface upon P modification. Changes in the chemical state and local coordination environment of the Pt NPs via P modification were further investigated using XAS after reduction at 600 °C to examine the formation of the Pt–P alloy. The normalized X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectra of the Pt L3-edge of 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 are shown in Fig. 3(a). Unmodified 1Pt–0P/Al2O3 exhibits a representative edge energy of 11,564 eV and a white line intensity similar to previous results for Pt foil, indicating that metallic Pt species were dominant in the Pt NPs [13,15,19,33,34]. The addition of P led to a shift in the edge energy toward a higher value for 1Pt–1P/Al2O3. As the P content increased, 1Pt–3P/Al2O3 and 1Pt–5P/Al2O3 exhibited higher edge energies, evidencing the modification of the Pt NPs with P. Similarly, the white line intensity increased with increasing P content in 1Pt–xP/Al2O3, indicating a decrease in the electron density of the Pt and the presence of Pt species with higher oxidation states. These changes in the Pt L3-edge spectra are consistent with previous observations of the formation of Pt–P alloys [19,29]. Fig. 3(b) shows the k 2-weighted magnitudes of the Fourier transforms of the extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectra of 1Pt–xP/Al2O3, which reveal distinct peaks indicative of the coordination environment within the catalysts. The unmodified 1Pt–0P/Al2O3 exhibited three peaks between 1.5 and 3.0 Å (phase uncorrected), similar to a previously reported Pt–Pt peak position of monometallic Pt catalysts [35,36]. However, P-modified Pt catalysts showed a broader peak between 1.2 and 3.0 Å, encompassing the Pt–Pt peak of 1Pt–0P/Al2O3. Previous XAS studies on noble metal–P alloys, including Pt–P alloys, have demonstrated that the formation of metal–P bonds results in the emergence of a new peak at around 1.0–2.0 Å (phase uncorrected) [18,19,37]. Thus, broadening the peak toward shorter distances implies the presence of Pt–P alloy in the Pt NPs of the P-modified catalysts. The CN and bond distance for Pt–Pt and Pt–P scattering in 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 catalysts were quantitatively evaluated by fitting the EXAFS data (Table S6 and Fig. S6). The unmodified 1Pt–0P/Al2O3 catalyst exhibited Pt–Pt scattering with a CN of 6.9 at 2.72 Å, similar to previously reported values for supported Pt catalysts [38]. However, the P modification decreased the Pt–Pt coordination compared to 1Pt–0P/Al2O3, leading to the lowest CN of 4.8 at 2.71 Å. The decrease in CN of the Pt–Pt scattering is attributed to the formation of a Pt–P scattering, with CN of 1.3–1.4 at around 2.30 Å. It is also noteworthy that the Pt–P scattering contrasts with the Pt–O scattering (2.04 Å) [38]. Thus, the broadening of the peak toward shorter distances and the emergence of Pt–P scattering at around 2.30 Å confirmed the presence of both metallic Pt and Pt–P alloy in the Pt NPs of the P-modified catalysts. The effect of P modification on the electronic state of the Pt NPs was investigated by comparing the XPS profiles of the 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 catalysts ( Fig. 4). The Pt 4d5/2 peaks in the spectra were deconvoluted into a peak at 314.5 eV, corresponding to metallic Pt0 species, and a peak at 318.2 eV, corresponding to Ptδ+ (2 ≤ δ ≤ 4) species [39,40]. The analysis of the unmodified 1Pt–0P/Al2O3 catalyst revealed that the surface of the Pt NPs was predominantly in the Pt0 state. The Ptδ+/Pt0 ratio increased with increasing P content in the 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 catalysts (Table S7), implying an increasing fraction of Pt–P alloy on the Pt NP surfaces. Moreover, the Pt 4d peaks shifted by 0.4 eV to higher binding energies with an increasing P content. This is consistent with previous observations for metal–P alloys, such as Pt2P, Rh2P, and RuP, in which alloy formation led to a shift in the peaks toward higher binding energies in the XPS spectra of the metals [18,30,41]. The P-modified Pt/Al2O3 catalysts showed P 2p peaks at 134.1–134.2 eV (Fig. S7), mainly due to the P5+ species on the Al2O3 support [42]. The surface concentration of 1Pt-xP/Al2O3 catalysts confirmed a decrease in the relative concentration of Pt and an increase in that of P as the amount of added P increased (Table S8). Based on the analysis of the XPS, XAS, CO chemisorption, and STEM images, we concluded that the introduction of P into the Pt NPs, followed by high-temperature treatment under a reducing H2 atmosphere, resulted in the formation of a Pt–P alloy. Consequently, both the Pt–P alloys and metallic Pt coexisted on the surface of the Pt NPs in the 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 catalysts. Notably, this observation for Pt/Al2O3 is significantly different from that for Pt/SiO2. In Pt/SiO2, a similar modification with an equivalent P content resulted in complete alloying, leading to the formation of a non-metallic PtP2 surface containing Pt2+ ions [19]. However, possibly owing to a stronger interaction between P and the Al2O3 support compared to that with the SiO2 support, a moderate level of alloying occurs between P and Pt, leading to the presence of both the Pt–P alloy and metallic Pt on the surface of the Pt NPs. 3.2 Catalytic performance of 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 catalysts for PDH The performance of the 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 catalysts for PDH was evaluated at 600 °C ( Table 2 and Fig. 5). Before the measurements, all catalysts were pretreated in a H2 atmosphere for 1 h at the reaction temperature. The turnover frequency of propane (TOFpropane) values of 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 were calculated from the initial propane conversion values using the number of surface Pt atoms determined by CO chemisorption. In the absence of Pt NPs, the P-modified Al2O3 support showed negligible propane conversion, even under more favorable conditions, confirming that Pt is the active material for PDH (Fig. S8). The unmodified 1Pt–0P/Al2O3 catalyst exhibited an initial TOFpropane of 1.4 s–1 and a moderate propylene selectivity of 83% at WHSVpropane = 23.6 h–1. However, P-modified 1Pt–1P/Al2O3 showed an increased TOFpropane of 1.8 s–1 and a selectivity of 95%, revealing a synergistic effect of the coexistence of the Pt–P alloy and metallic Pt species on the catalytic performance of PDH. The higher P content in 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 led to a further increase in TOFpropane of up to 3.7 s–1 and selectivity of up to 98% for 1Pt–5P/Al2O3. In terms of the space-time yield of propylene (STYpropylene), P modification improved the performance of 1Pt–1P/Al2O3 compared to 1Pt–0P/Al2O3, leading to the highest STYpropylene of 16.9 mmol·kgcat –1·s–1. However, the STYpropylene of 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 gradually decreased with increasing P content. This was due to the formation of excess Pt–P alloy species at the expense of metallic Pt on the NP surface, as confirmed by the decrease in the amount of chemisorbed CO (Table 1). Previous study of PDH over PtP2/SiO2 catalysts has shown that despite a high propylene selectivity, a non-metallic PtP2 surface containing Pt2+ ions exhibits a significantly low dehydrogenation activity for propane compared to that of Pt/SiO2 catalyst [19]. The promoting effect of P on propylene selectivity was demonstrated by comparing the product selectivities of 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 over a wide range of propane conversions (Fig. 5(d)). For all propane conversions, the P-modified catalysts exhibited higher propylene selectivity than the unmodified catalyst. The higher selectivity of the P-modified catalysts was more pronounced at higher conversion levels because the unmodified 1Pt–0P/Al2O3 exhibited a significant decrease in selectivity with conversion. Thus, these results indicate that metallic Pt is the main active species for propane dehydrogenation but the formation of the Pt–P alloy in 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 promotes the selective formation of propylene and inhibits side reactions during PDH. The improved selectivity of the P-modified 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 catalysts toward propylene was confirmed by repeated reactions (Fig. S9). During six consecutive reaction-regeneration cycles, 1Pt–0P/Al2O3 and 1Pt–1P/Al2O3 revealed similar deactivation behaviors, with a gradual decrease in conversion, as commonly observed for PDH over Pt-based catalysts. The HRTEM image of the spent 1Pt–0P/Al2O3 catalyst after the first reaction step shows that the particle sizes are between 1–2 nm (Fig. S10(a)). The negligible change in particle size before and after the reaction indicates that the deactivation observed during PDH was due to the coke deposition on active sites. However, after regeneration in an air stream, the regenerated catalyst had aggregated NPs of approximately 4–7 nm (Fig. S10(b)). This suggests that the aggregation of NPs during the regeneration also reduces the conversion when cycles are repeated, particularly in the first three cycles. After the last sixth reaction, the spent 1Pt–0P/Al2O3 catalyst had the aggregated NPs between 6–10 nm (Fig. S10(c)). Similarly, compared to the fresh 1Pt–1P/Al2O3, the spent catalyst showed larger NPs with an average diameter of 5.5 nm after the six consecutive cycles (Fig. S11). Despite the gradual decrease in conversion, 1Pt–1P/Al2O3 exhibited a higher selectivity than 1Pt–0 P/Al2O3 during repeated cycles. The EDS images of the spent 1Pt–1P/Al2O3 catalyst confirm the coexistence of Pt and P species on the NP surface (Fig. S12). Thus, this suggests that the presence of the Pt-P alloy maintained the promoting effect of the P-modification throughout the reactions, despite the aggregation of the NPs. For the 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 catalysts, E a values were estimated using the Arrhenius equation over the temperature range of 520–580 °C ( Fig. 6). The unmodified 1Pt–0P/Al2O3 catalyst exhibited an E a of 40 kJ∙mol–1, which is similar to previously reported values for Pt/Al2O3 catalysts [43–45]. The modification with P resulted in a decrease in the E a of 1Pt–1P/Al2O3 to 29 kJ·mol–1. With increasing P content, 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 exhibited a decrease in E a, reaching a minimum of 17 kJ·mol–1 for 1Pt–5P/Al2O3. Both experimental and theoretical studies on Pt-based catalysts have shown that smaller Pt ensembles have a lower E a for dehydrogenation [43,46]. Thus, our findings suggest that the improvement in the catalytic performance of the 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 catalysts can be attributed to the fragmentation of large Pt ensembles into smaller ones via Pt–P alloying. 3.3 Inhibition of side reactions over P-modified 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 catalysts Owing to the high capacity of Pt-based catalysts to activate C–H bonds, they are rapidly deactivated by coke formation during the PDH reaction at high C3H8 partial pressures (Fig. S13) [3,47]. Introducing an appropriate amount of H2 with C3H8 can alleviate severe coke formation and increase catalytic performance. However, excess H2 can lead to undesirable side reactions, decreasing propylene selectivity and STYpropylene. To investigate the change in catalytic performance of 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 catalysts with H2 partial pressure, the feed ratio of H2/C3H8 was varied from 0.5 to 2 ( Fig. 7 and Fig. S14). The unmodified 1Pt–0P/Al2O3 exhibited an increase in STYpropylene with increasing H2 partial pressure due to increased activity. However, the propylene selectivity of 1Pt–0P/Al2O3 decreased from 87% to 71%, indicating that an excessive amount of H2 significantly degrades the selective dehydrogenation of propane to propylene over a bare Pt surface. The 1Pt–1P/Al2O3 exhibited higher STYpropylene than the other 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 catalysts at all feed ratios. Increasing the feed ratio from H2/C3H8 = 0.5 to 1 resulted in the highest STYpropylene with increased activity and maintained propylene selectivity. When the feed ratio was further increased to H2/C3H8 = 2, the selectivity and STYpropylene of 1Pt–1P/Al2O3 decreased slightly. However, 1Pt–3P/Al2O3 and 1Pt–5P/Al2O3 catalysts with higher P content exhibited similar propylene selectivity and STYpropylene regardless of the feed ratio, suggesting that Pt–P alloy species effectively suppressed undesired side reactions at high H2 partial pressure. The product selectivities of the 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 catalysts at various feed ratios of H2/C3H8 provide insights into the higher propylene selectivity of the catalysts after P modification ( Fig. 8). The lower propylene selectivity of 1Pt–0P/Al2O3 is mainly owing to the production of undesired ethane and methane. In particular, the formation of ethane increased considerably from 2.4% to 13.2% as the H2 partial pressure increased from H2/C3H8 = 0.5 to 2. This suggests that the desired dehydrogenation reaction is inhibited by the hydrogenolysis of propane, which is a common side reaction on Pt surfaces. The modification of Pt/Al2O3 with P effectively suppressed undesired hydrogenolysis, significantly lowering the ethane selectivity of 1Pt–1P/Al2O3 to 3.7% at a feed ratio of H2/C3H8 = 2. The higher P content in 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 further prevented ethane production, resulting in only 0.7% ethane selectivity. The inhibition of side reactions over the P-modified 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 catalysts was further examined using C3H8-TPSR spectroscopy in a flow of C3H8 and H2 (Fig. S15). The unmodified Pt catalyst exhibited a noticeable reduction in the signals of H2 and C3H8 at around 330 °C, leading to the appearance of CH4 and C2H6 desorption peaks corresponding to the hydrogenolysis products of C3H8. Desorption signals of the products of PDH (C3H6 and H2) and cracking (CH4) were observed above 450 °C. In contrast to the unmodified Pt catalyst, the 1Pt–1P/Al2O3 catalyst resulted in a dominant increase in the signals of PDH products above 450 °C, with no decrease in the signals of H2 and C3H8 at 330 °C. Previous studies have shown that the addition of Sn to Pt NPs inhibits the hydrogenolysis reaction by reducing the size of the Pt ensembles [16,48]. Our results suggest that the formation of Pt–P alloys induces an effect similar to that observed in the case of Pt–Sn alloys. The improvement in the catalytic performance of the P-modified 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 was attributed to a significant increase in propylene selectivity. Our characterization results suggest that the enhancement was closely related to the formation of Pt–P alloy species, which coexist with metallic Pt. The influence of P modification on the structure of the Pt surface was investigated using the DRIFT spectra of the CO adsorbed on 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 ( Fig. 9). The CO probe molecules were specifically adsorbed on Pt sites, resulting in two intense bands at 2000–2100 and 1700–1900 cm–1 in the DRIFT spectra of the catalysts. The bands at higher and lower wavenumbers are attributed to linearly bonded CO species (L) and bridged and multi-bonded CO species (M), respectively [49–53]. The change in the M/L intensity ratio provides insights into the structure of the Pt surface because bridged and multi-bonded CO species are preferentially formed on large and flat Pt ensembles [49,53]. Among the 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 catalysts, unmodified 1Pt–0P/Al2O3 exhibited the most intense bands in the DRIFT spectra of adsorbed CO on the Pt catalysts, and the shape of the spectrum was similar to that of previously reported Pt/Al2O3 catalysts [32,54]. The intensities of the bands decreased with increasing P content in 1Pt–xP/Al2O3. This is consistent with the CO chemisorption results, indicating a decrease in the fraction of metallic Pt on the NP surface with increasing P content. Unmodified 1Pt–0P/Al2O3 had the highest M/L ratio of 0.17, which gradually decreased to 0.02 with increasing P content, indicating a decrease in the size of ensembles due to the formation of alloy species on the NP surface [32,55]. Studies on several Pt–M alloy catalysts, including Pt–Ga, Pt–Sn, Pt–Mn, and Pt–Co, have shown that alloying elements induce geometric effects, whereby large Pt ensembles are split into smaller ones, which suppresses structure-sensitive hydrogenolysis and cracking reactions [13,16,56,57]. Thus, the DRIFT spectra of adsorbed CO on 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 provide evidence for the effective inhibition of hydrogenolysis of P-modified Pt catalysts compared to that of monometallic Pt catalysts owing to the geometric effect of the Pt–P alloy. The inhibition of coke formation via P modification was also investigated by quantifying the amount of coke deposited on the 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 catalysts after 2 h of reaction ( Table 3 and Fig. S16). The amount of deposited coke followed the order 1Pt–0P/Al2O3 (4.1%) > 1Pt–1P/Al2O3 (2.7%) > 1Pt–3P/Al2O3 (1.6%) > 1Pt–5P/Al2O3 (1.3%). In particular, a comparison of the amounts of coke on 1Pt–0P/Al2O3 and 1Pt–1P/Al2O3, which exhibited similar propane conversions, confirmed that modification with P suppressed coke formation. Because acidic properties generally affect coke formation over supported catalysts, the total amount and distribution of acid sites on the 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 catalysts were investigated via NH3-TPD (Table 3 and Fig. S17). The 1Pt–0P/Al2O3 catalysts exhibited acidic properties similar to that of the bare γ-Al2O3 support, with a broad peak between 100 and 500 °C in the NH3-TPD spectrum. Modification with P led to a noticeable decrease in the total number of acid sites of 1Pt–1P/Al2O3 and 1Pt–3P/Al2O3 with increasing P content. In particular, the introduction of P species decreased the density of the medium and strong acid sites, which contributed to coke formation [58–60]. A further increase in the P content led to a slight decrease in the number of acid sites, where 1Pt–5P/Al2O3 and 1Pt–3P/Al2O3 exhibited similar acidity. The decrease in the number of acid sites upon modification with P was consistent with the amount of coke deposition. Therefore, the introduction of P species into the 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 catalysts efficiently prevented coke formation by reducing the density of medium and strong acid sites. Because of P modification, the 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 catalysts with both Pt–P alloys and metallic Pt species exhibited a remarkable improvement in propylene selectivity while maintaining catalytic activity. The decrease in the size of the Pt ensembles and the number of acid sites effectively inhibited side reactions such as hydrogenolysis, cracking, and coke formation. Our results emphasize the beneficial effects of modifying Pt catalysts with P for the selective production of propylene in PDH. 4 Conclusions In this study, we prepared P-modified 1Pt–xP/Al2O3 catalysts via sequential impregnation to enhance their catalytic performance for PDH. Modification of the catalysts with P led to the coexistence of metallic Pt and Pt–P alloys on the surface of the Pt NPs. The P-modified Pt/Al2O3 catalysts demonstrated a remarkable improvement in propylene selectivity under various feed conditions compared to that of the unmodified control. Moreover, the optimal modified catalyst exhibited no decrease in propylene productivity, despite the loss of some metallic Pt sites owing to the formation of the Pt–P alloy. The enhanced propylene selectivity is attributed to the effective suppression of side reactions, hydrogenolysis, cracking, and coke formation during PDH. The effective inhibition of the side reactions by P modification originates from the reduction in the size of the Pt ensembles by the formation of a Pt–P alloy and the decrease in the density of acid sites. These findings highlight the positive effect of P on Pt catalysts and emphasize the synergistic effect of coexisting Pt and Pt–P on the surface of Pt NPs in the design of PDH catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The rigorous operating conditions required for propane dehydrogenation result in undesired side reactions on Pt catalysts. Herein, we present the successful suppression of structure-sensitive side reactions by modifying Pt/Al2O3 catalysts with P. The characterization of the P-modified Pt/Al2O3 catalysts revealed the coexistence of metallic Pt and Pt–P alloys on the surfaces of the Pt nanoparticles. At a reaction temperature of 600 °C, the Pt catalyst modified with an optimal amount of P exhibited a notably higher propylene selectivity (95%) than that of the unmodified Pt/Al2O3 catalyst (typically ∼83%), without any loss of activity. A detailed investigation revealed that the geometric effect resulting from the formation of the Pt–P alloy, which reduced the size of the Pt ensembles, was mainly responsible for the enhanced performance of P-modified Pt/Al2O3. This study offers vital insights into the formation of noble metal–P alloys on nanoparticle surfaces and their advantageous effects on heterogeneous catalysis.
coredata.dc:title: P-modified Pt/Al2O3 catalysts for selective propane dehydrogenation
